metadata.sermon_start_end: Some of you will remember the TV ads from AT&T a bit ago. They featured a winsome young teacher or librarian, sitting at a table with young children. He engaged them in friendly talk through a series of questions. The questions of course led to the conclusion that we [...] My soul clings to you; your right hand upholds me. (Ps. 63:5–8) ‘Tis a gift to come down where we ought to be!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific pericope. It jumps between Isaiah 55, Luke 13, and Psalm 63. Consequently, it treats the texts as illustrations for a pre-determined theme ('Empire vs. Gospel') rather than letting a specific text say what can be found nowhere else. The uniqueness of the Isaiah passage is flattened into a general contrast with modern consumerism.
quotes: And then, right in the middle of their busyness... Isaiah disrupts with his poem
But then there is this abrasive Gospel lesson with its hard sayings
So the Psalm for the day ends in trusting satisfaction
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope—either Isaiah 55 or Luke 13—and excavate its unique theological claim. Avoid using multiple texts to support a general 'Lent' theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a brief mention of the Babylonian exile, which provides some context for Isaiah. However, the exegesis is superficial. There is no evidence of engagement with the original languages or the specific theological tensions within the biblical books. The 'empire' of Babylon is too quickly equated with AT&T ads without exploring the specific religious-political reality of the first readers.
quotes: And back in ancient Babylon, the Jewish exiles were productive. They wanted to get ahead in the Babylonian Empire
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the historical-critical analysis. What did 'wine and milk without money' mean specifically to a destitute exile? Move beyond sociological generalizations.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its description of the 'zeitgeist' (productivity, AT&T, 'big is better'). It identifies the psychological state of the modern hearer well. However, it borders on being a 'speech about refugees/empire' rather than a sermon, as the application becomes a general critique of capitalism rather than a specific spiritual direction derived from the text.
quotes: It featured a winsome young teacher or librarian... The questions of course led to the conclusion that we should buy AT&T products.
Fourth Church is that reference point for this God in the season of Lent who disrupts our life
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application is not just a cultural critique but a specific 're-creation' of the Word for the congregation's spiritual life.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is relatively successful in mixing exposition and application. It does not follow a 'lecture then moral' structure. Instead, it attempts to draw the Babylonian exile and the Chicago 'Magnificent Mile' professional into the same movement of the text.
quotes: They were willing to participate in the greed... Not a bad question for us in Lent.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Strengthen the movement so that the 'present of revelation' is felt more urgently, rather than just a comparison of two similar situations.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories are present in the background. 'Misery' is identified as the 'rat-race' and 'anxiety.' 'Redemption' is the 'free gift' and 'pardon.' 'Gratitude' is the 'new productivity.' However, the misery is described more in sociological/psychological terms than as misery 'before God.'
quotes: Why do you pursue greed and anxiety that will never make you happy?
Our God will abundantly pardon and take you as you are.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the sense of 'misery' beyond 'unhappiness' to the theological reality of being lost before God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'two ways' via the Luke passage ('unless you repent, you will all perish'). However, it immediately softens this by suggesting we only 'disappear into the woodwork of the empire.' The radicality of being 'lost'—especially eternal loss—is avoided in favor of 'forfeiting identity.'
quotes: Unless you repent, you will all perish. (Luke 13:3)
Isaiah suggests, rather, that if we do not change, our faith will evaporate and we will disappear into the woodwork of the empire.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Do not explain away the 'perishing' in the text. Take the possibility of being lost as seriously as the text does, without turning it into a mere metaphor for loss of 'faith identity'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is a significant weakness. Christ is mentioned only in passing as the one who says the hard words in Luke. He is not the 'telos' of the sermon. The sermon is more 'Theocentric' or 'Prophetic-Ethical' than Christocentric. Grace is offered as a 'free gift' from God, but the specific role of Christ (the two natures, His life as our life) is absent.
quotes: Jesus says to his hearers: Unless you repent...
Be a Christian, not a rat-raced consumer
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the goal (telos) of the sermon. How does this specific text point to the 'whole Christ' as our salvation outside ourselves?

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker (and Miskotte), this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for theological depth. The brevity contributes to the lack of serious exegesis and the rapid jumping between texts.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon to at least 20 minutes (approx. 2000 words) to allow the text to truly 'unfold' and for the exegesis to breathe.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of focus on a single Bible passage and its insufficient length. It functions more as a thematic reflection on 'Empire vs. Gospel' than as an exposition of the Word of God. While it effectively identifies the zeitgeist of the 'productive' hearer, it lacks a robust Christological telos and softens the biblical warning of perishing into a loss of 'identity.'
strengths: Effective identification of the cultural 'zeitgeist' (the AT&T ad/productivity trap).
Good interwovenness of the biblical world and the contemporary world.
Clear call to the 'free gift' of grace as an alternative to merit-based living.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific pericope (Thesis 1.3).
Insufficient length (11 minutes) to achieve theological depth (Thesis 8).
Weak Christology; Christ is a teacher/prophet rather than the ontological telos (Thesis 7).
Softening of the 'two ways'; 'perishing' is reduced to sociological disappearance (Thesis 6).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker’s definition. It is an insightful religious address or a 'speech about the gospel,' but it lacks the specific exegetical grounding and the Christological weight required to be a 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current, proclamatory word.'
